fields: Who coined the term "cell" after observing cork under the microscope?

Question
Who coined the term "cell" after observing cork under the microscope?

Correct answer: C â€” Hooke

Core idea (exam focus)
Term â€˜cellâ€™ was introduced from early microscopy of cork.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Robert Hooke (1665) described â€˜cellsâ€™ in cork (dead plant tissue).
  • Schleiden and Schwann later formulated cell theory.
  • Virchow added â€˜omnis cellula e cellulaâ€™ (cells come from cells).


Why the other options are not
  • A: Schleiden: plants are made of cells (cell theory).
  • B: Schwann: animals are made of cells (cell theory).
  • D: Virchow: cells arise from preâ€‘existing cells.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Hooke = coined â€˜cellâ€™.
  • Schleiden + Schwann = cell theory.
  • Virchow = â€˜cells from cellsâ€™.
Which microscope technique allows observation of living cells without staining?

Question
Which microscope technique allows observation of living cells without staining?

Correct answer: C â€” Phase-contrast

Core idea (exam focus)
Phase-contrast enhances contrast in transparent living cells.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Phase-contrast converts phase shifts (from refractive index differences) into brightness differences.
  • Allows viewing of unstained, living cells.


Why the other options are not
  • A: Bright-field usually needs staining for contrast.
  • B: Fluorescence needs fluorescent labels/dyes.
  • D: Electron microscopy requires fixed, dead specimens in vacuum.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Phaseâ€‘contrast = live, unstained cells.
  • Electron microscopy = fixed/dead.
Which technique uses labeled antibodies for detecting specific molecules?

Question
Which technique uses labeled antibodies for detecting specific molecules?

Correct answer: C â€” Immunohistochemistry

Core idea (exam focus)
Immunohistochemistry uses antibodies to detect specific antigens.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Primary/secondary antibodies bind target proteins; label gives signal (enzyme/fluorophore).


Why the other options are not
  • A: Histochemistry stains chemical constituents without antibody specificity.
  • B: Autoradiography detects radioisotope-labeled molecules.
  • D: Phaseâ€‘contrast is an imaging method, not molecular labeling.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Antibodies â†’ antigen specificity.
  • IHC localizes proteins in cells/tissues.
Which structure level is immediately higher than macromolecules in cell organization?

Correct answer: A â€” Supramolecular complexes

Core idea (must know)

In the hierarchy of cell organization, supramolecular complexes are the level immediately above macromolecules.

Mechanistic hierarchy (high-yield order)

From smaller â†’ larger:
  1. Macromolecules (proteins, lipids, nucleic acids)
  2. Supramolecular complexes (ribosomes, membranes, cytoskeleton filaments)
  3. Organelles
  4. Cells
  5. Tissues

Why this is tested (exam logic)

  • Supramolecular complexes are non-covalent assemblies of macromolecules.
  • They represent the first functional organization level beyond single molecules.

Why the other options are wrong

  • B Organelles â†’ composed of many supramolecular complexes
  • C Cells â†’ higher level, contain organelles
  • D Tissues â†’ multicellular organization

Typical exam traps

  • Jumping directly from macromolecules â†’ organelles (skips a level)
  • Forgetting that membranes and ribosomes are not organelles themselves, but supramolecular complexes

One-line rule to remember

Macromolecules â†’ Supramolecular complexes â†’ Organelles
What is the main component of the cytoskeleton responsible for cell shape and motility?

Correct answer: B â€” Microtubules

High-yield explanation (exam-oriented)

Core idea (1â€“2 lines):
Microtubules are the primary cytoskeletal element responsible for maintaining cell shape and enabling cell motility, especially via cilia, flagella, and intracellular transport.

Mechanism

  • Structure: Hollow tubes made of Î±- and Î²-tubulin dimers (13 protofilaments).
  • Polarity: Plus and minus ends allow directional transport.
  • Dynamics: Rapid polymerization/depolymerization (â€œdynamic instabilityâ€) enables shape changes and movement.

Why this fits shape and motility

  • Cell shape: Microtubules act as internal â€œstrutsâ€ that resist compression.
  • Motility:
    • Form the axoneme (9+2 structure) of cilia and flagella â†’ active movement
    • Serve as tracks for kinesin and dynein â†’ intracellular transport critical for cell polarization and migration
  • Cell division: Form the mitotic spindle, indirectly influencing shape and movement during mitosis.

Why the other options are incorrect

  • A. Microfilaments (actin): Important for cortical tension and local movement, but not the main determinant of overall cell shape and motility.
  • C. Intermediate filaments: Provide tensile strength, mechanical stability, not motility.
  • D. Myosin: A motor protein, not a cytoskeletal component itself.
  • E. None: Incorrect because microtubules clearly fulfill this role.

Clinical correlation (often tested)

  • Defects in microtubules â†’ primary ciliary dyskinesia, impaired sperm motility, respiratory infections.
  • Anti-mitotic drugs (e.g., colchicine, vincristine) target microtubules.
Which cells are the largest in the human body?

ðŸ“Œ Core idea (MU Varna exam focus)

When asked for the largest cell, exams usually refer to cell diameter/volume, not length.


ðŸ§  Mechanism / reasoning

  • Oocytes have the largest diameter and volume of any human cell (â‰ˆ 100â€“120 Âµm)
  • They accumulate abundant cytoplasm, organelles, and maternal mRNA to support early embryonic development
Important distinction:
  • Neurons can be the longest cells (e.g. motor neurons up to ~1 m)
  • But they are not the largest by volume

ðŸ©º Clinical integration (first-doctor perspective)

  • Oocyte size reflects its role in sustaining the embryo before placental support
  • Oocyte quality (cytoplasmic content) is crucial in fertility and IVF outcomes

âŒ Why the other options are not correct

A. Red blood cells
Very small (~7â€“8 Âµm), anucleate, specialized for gas transport.
B. Neurons
Longest cells, but relatively small cell bodies compared to oocytes.
D. Purkinje cells
Large neurons with extensive dendritic trees, but still smaller in volume than oocytes.

â­ Exam gold (high-yield takeaway)

  • Largest cell (by volume): oocyte
  • Longest cell: neuron
If the question does not specify â€œlongest,â€ always choose oocyte.
Which of the following organelles is not membrane-bound:

Question
Which of the following is a non-membranous organelle?

Correct answer: E â€” Ribosome

Core idea (exam focus)
Ribosomes are non-membrane-bound organelles.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Ribosomes are rRNA + proteins; free in cytosol or bound to RER.
  • Membrane-bound organelles include ER, Golgi, lysosomes, mitochondria.


Why the other options are not
  • A: Lysosomes are membrane-bound.
  • B: Golgi apparatus is membrane-bound.
  • D: Mitochondria are double-membraned.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Non-membranous: ribosomes, cytoskeleton, centrioles.
  • Membranous: ER, Golgi, lysosome, mitochondria.
Which cytoplasmic component stores lipids and glycogen?

Correct answer: C â€” Inclusions

High-yield cytology explanation (MU-Varna style)

  • Cytoplasmic inclusions are non-living, non-membrane-bound accumulations within the cytoplasm.
  • They serve as storage materials, including:
    • Lipids (lipid droplets)
    • Glycogen (glycogen granules)
    • Pigments (e.g., melanin, lipofuscin)
Therefore, lipids and glycogen are stored as cytoplasmic inclusions.

Why the other options are wrong (classic traps)

  • A Organelles â†’ membrane-bound functional units (mitochondria, ER, Golgi)
  • B Cytosol â†’ fluid matrix; substances are dissolved, not stored as discrete bodies
  • D Nucleolus â†’ ribosomal RNA synthesis, nuclear structure

One-line exam rule

Storage without membrane = cytoplasmic inclusions.

Clinical correlation (often implicit)

Excess lipid or glycogen inclusions â†’ steatosis or glycogen storage diseases.
The glycocalyx is primarily composed of:

Correct answer: B â€” Glycoproteins and glycolipids




Core idea (exam focus)

The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich surface coat on the extracellular side of the plasma membrane.

Mechanism / composition

  • Built from oligosaccharide chains attached to:
    • Glycoproteins
    • Glycolipids
  • These carbohydrate chains project outward, forming a protective and functional layer.

Clinical / functional integration

  • Cellâ€“cell recognition and adhesion (e.g., immune interactions)
  • Protection of the cell surface
  • Receptor binding and signaling
  • Important in epithelial cells, endothelium, and intestinal brush border

Why the other options are incorrect

  • A â€” Lipids and nucleic acids: Nucleic acids are not membrane surface components.
  • C â€” Phospholipids: Form the lipid bilayer, not the glycocalyx.
  • D â€” Intermediate filaments: Cytoskeletal elements inside the cell.

Exam gold (high-yield)

If the stem mentions cell surface coat, carbohydrate layer, or cell recognition, think
glycoproteins + glycolipids â†’ glycocalyx.
Which structure is responsible for protein synthesis for secretion?

Correct answer: C â€” Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER)

1ï¸âƒ£ Core rule (must-know)

All proteins destined for secretion are synthesized on ribosomes bound to the Rough ER.
If you see â€œfor secretionâ€, your answer should be RER automatically.

2ï¸âƒ£ Mechanism (why this is true)

  • Secretory proteins contain an N-terminal signal peptide.
  • This signal is recognized by the Signal Recognition Particle (SRP).
  • The ribosome is directed to the RER membrane.
  • Translation continues with the protein being:
    • Inserted into the RER lumen (secreted proteins), or
    • Inserted into the membrane (membrane proteins).
From there:
RER â†’ Golgi â†’ secretory vesicles â†’ exocytosis

3ï¸âƒ£ Why the other options are wrong (exam reminders)

  • A â€” Smooth ER
    âŒ Lipid synthesis, detoxification, CaÂ²âº storage; no ribosomes
  • B â€” Free ribosomes
    âŒ Cytosolic proteins only (e.g., enzymes, cytoskeleton proteins)
  • D â€” Nucleolus
    âŒ rRNA synthesis and ribosome assembly, not protein synthesis

4ï¸âƒ£ Clinical / exam integration

  • Plasma cells (antibody secretion) â†’ abundant RER
  • Pancreatic acinar cells (digestive enzymes) â†’ very prominent RER
  • Expect MU-Varna questions linking RER + basophilia + secretory cells
The Golgi apparatus modifies and packages proteins mainly in its:

Correct answer: C â€” Trans face

Core idea (exam focus)

The Golgi apparatus is polarized. While proteins are received and modified as they pass through the stack, final processing, sorting, and packaging occur at the trans face.

Functional organization (stepwise)

  • Cis face: receives proteins from the rough ER.
  • Medial cisternae: perform stepwise modifications (e.g., glycosylation trimming/addition).
  • Trans face (trans-Golgi network):
    • Final modification
    • Sorting
    • Packaging into vesicles destined for secretion, plasma membrane, or lysosomes.
Because the question asks where proteins are mainly modified and packaged, the best single answer is the trans face.

Why the other options are not correct

  • A â€” Cis face: Entry/receiving side, not packaging.
  • B â€” Medial cisternae: Important for modification, but not packaging.
  • D â€” Rough ER: Protein synthesis, not Golgi processing or packaging.

Exam gold (high-yield)

Think â€œcis in â†’ trans out.â€
If the stem mentions sorting or packaging, the answer is almost always trans face.

ðŸ“Œ Core idea (MU Varna exam focus)

Lysosomal enzymes are acid hydrolases. They become functionally active only after fusion with vesicles that provide an acidic environment.


ðŸ§  Mechanism / reasoning

  • Lysosomal enzymes are synthesized in the rough ER as inactive precursors
  • They are processed in the Golgi apparatus and tagged (e.g., mannose-6-phosphate)
  • True enzymatic activity requires:
    • Fusion with endosomes/phagosomes
    • Low pH (~4.5â€“5) created by proton pumps (Hâº-ATPase)
Thus:
  • Fusion â†’ acidification â†’ activation
This protects the cell from self-digestion if enzymes leak.

ðŸ©º Clinical integration (first-doctor perspective)

  • Defects in lysosomal enzyme targeting or activation cause lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., I-cell disease)
  • Failure of vesicle fusion impairs autophagy and intracellular digestion

âŒ Why the other options are not correct

A. They are synthesized
At synthesis, enzymes are inactive to prevent cellular damage.
C. They reach the nucleus
Lysosomal enzymes never function in the nucleus.
D. They are excreted
They are designed for intracellular digestion, not secretion.

â­ Exam gold (high-yield takeaway)

  • Neutral pH â†’ enzymes inactive
  • Acidic vesicle â†’ enzymes active
  • Key words: acid hydrolases, fusion, low pH
The main function of peroxisomes is:

Question
The main function of peroxisomes is:

Correct answer: D â€” Detoxification

Core idea (exam focus)
Peroxisomes perform oxidative reactions and detoxify H2O2.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Contain oxidases and catalase; Î²-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids.
  • Detoxification (e.g., H2O2 breakdown) and plasmalogen synthesis.


Why the other options are not
  • A: Protein synthesis is ribosomes/RER.
  • B: ATP synthesis is mitochondria.
  • C: Not correct for this stem.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Catalase = hallmark enzyme.
  • VLCFA Î²-oxidation = peroxisome.
Which structure has cristae and functions in ATP synthesis?

Question
Which structure has cristae and functions in ATP synthesis?

Correct answer: C â€” Mitochondrion

Core idea (exam focus)
Mitochondrial inner membrane cristae house ETC and ATP synthase.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Proton gradient across inner membrane drives ATP synthase (oxidative phosphorylation).


Why the other options are not
  • A: RER has cisternae, not cristae.
  • B: Golgi has stacks, not cristae.
  • D: Lysosomes are acidic vesicles, not ATP factories.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Cristae increase inner membrane surface area.
  • ATP synthase on inner membrane.
The darker-staining, inactive part of chromatin is called:

Correct answer: C â€” Heterochromatin

High-yield cytology explanation (MU-Varna style)

  • Heterochromatin is:
    • Densely packed
    • Dark-staining (basophilic)
    • Transcriptionally inactive
  • Typically located:
    • At the nuclear periphery
    • Around the nucleolus
    • At centromeres and telomeres

Why the other options are wrong (classic traps)

  • A Euchromatin â†’ lightly stained, transcriptionally active
  • B Ribochromatin â†’ not a standard histological term (distractor)
  • D Plasmachromatin â†’ incorrect / obsolete term

One-line exam rule

Dark + dense + inactive = heterochromatin.

Clinical correlation (often implicit)

Increased heterochromatin â†’ low metabolic activity or cellular aging.
The nucleolus is the site for synthesis of:

Question
The nucleolus is the site for synthesis of:

Correct answer: C â€” rRNA

Core idea (exam focus)
Nucleolus produces rRNA and assembles ribosomal subunits.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Transcription of rRNA + processing + ribosomal protein assembly â†’ 40S/60S subunits.


Why the other options are not
  • A: DNA replication occurs in nucleus but not specifically nucleolus.
  • B: Not correct for this stem.
  • D: Protein synthesis occurs on ribosomes.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Nucleolus = rRNA + ribosome assembly.
In interphase, which structure separates cytoplasm from nucleoplasm?

Correct answer: D â€” Nuclear envelope

ðŸ“Œ Core idea (MU Varna exam focus)

During interphase, the nuclear envelope is the physical barrier that separates the cytoplasm from the nucleoplasm.

ðŸ§  Mechanism / reasoning

  • The nuclear envelope consists of two lipid bilayer membranes (inner and outer nuclear membranes)
  • It encloses the nucleus and maintains compartmentalization
  • Nuclear pores embedded in the envelope regulate selective transport (RNA, proteins)
Key contrasts:
  • Nuclear envelope â†’ separation
  • Nuclear lamina â†’ structural support

ðŸ©º Clinical integration (first-doctor perspective)

  • Breakdown of the nuclear envelope occurs during mitosis (prophase/prometaphase)
  • Defects in nuclear envelope/lamina proteins (e.g. lamins) cause laminopathies (muscular dystrophy, progeria)

âŒ Why the other options are not correct

A. Nuclear lamina
A protein meshwork lining the inner nuclear membrane; provides shape and anchoring, but does not separate compartments.
B. Plasma membrane
Separates the cell from the extracellular space, not nucleus from cytoplasm.
C. Rough ER
Site of protein synthesis; continuous with the outer nuclear membrane but not a boundary.

â­ Exam gold (high-yield takeaway)

  • Interphase â†’ intact nuclear envelope
  • Mitosis â†’ nuclear envelope breaks down
  • â€œSeparates cytoplasm from nucleoplasmâ€ = nuclear envelope
The basic unit of chromatin is the:

B) Nucleosome.


Why the Nucleosome is the Basic Unit

The nucleosome is often described as the "beads-on-a-string" structure of chromatin. It is the first level of DNA packaging in eukaryotic cells.
A single nucleosome consists of:
  • DNA segment: Approximately 147 base pairs of DNA.
  • Histone Octamer: A core of eight histone proteins (two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4).

Understanding the Other Options

To help clarify the differences between these related terms, here is a quick breakdown:
TermDefinitionRole in the Cell
HistoneA type of protein.Acts as the "spool" that DNA winds around; it's a component of the nucleosome, not the unit itself.
ChromatidOne-half of a replicated chromosome.Consists of many nucleosomes coiled tightly together; it's a much larger structural level.
CentromereA specific region of a chromosome.The specialized DNA sequence that joins two sister chromatids and attaches to spindle fibers during cell division.

Correct answer: D â€” Microtubule attachment
You chose B because your brain jumped to â€œspindleâ€“centrosomeâ€“mitosisâ€ as one bundle. This is a speed trap. Letâ€™s separate the structures cleanly so this never happens again.

1ï¸âƒ£ One rule that solves this instantly

Kinetochore = microtubule docking site on the centromere
If the option says microtubules, itâ€™s correct.
If it says centrosome, telomere, or replication, itâ€™s wrong.

2ï¸âƒ£ What the kinetochore actually is (mechanistic)

  • A protein complex assembled on the centromeric DNA
  • Appears in mitosis
  • Binds spindle microtubules
  • Enables:
    • Chromosome alignment
    • Sister chromatid separation
    • Spindle checkpoint signaling
So:
âœ… Microtubule attachment

3ï¸âƒ£ Why B feels right â€” and why it is wrong

B â€” Centrosome duplication
  • Centrosomes:
    • Duplicate in S phase
    • Organize the spindle poles
  • Kinetochores:
    • Are on chromosomes
    • Bind microtubules, not centrosomes
ðŸ“Œ Microtubules connect centrosomes to kinetochores, but kinetochores do not duplicate centrosomes.
This is a â€œconnected but not associatedâ€ trap.

4ï¸âƒ£ Why the others are wrong (quick hits)

  • A â€” Telomere replication âŒ
    Telomerase, chromosome ends
  • C â€” Chromatid cohesion âŒ
    Cohesin complex, not kinetochore

5ï¸âƒ£ One-line trap commitment (use this mentally)

Centrosome = spindle pole
Kinetochore = microtubule hook on the chromosome
Never swap pole and hook.

Correct answer: C â€” Simultaneous protein synthesis

Core idea (exam focus)

Polyribosomes (polysomes) are multiple ribosomes translating a single mRNA molecule at the same time, increasing efficiency of protein production.

Mechanism

  • One mRNA strand is bound by many ribosomes.
  • Each ribosome synthesizes an identical polypeptide concurrently.
  • This occurs in the cytosol or on the rough endoplasmic reticulum (for secretory and membrane proteins).

Clinical / functional integration

  • High polysome activity is seen in cells with high protein demand (e.g., plasma cells, hepatocytes).
  • On EM, abundant polyribosomes correlate with basophilia of the cytoplasm.

Why the other options are incorrect

  • A â€” DNA synthesis: Occurs in the nucleus during S phase.
  • B â€” Lipid storage: A function of adipocytes and lipid droplets.
  • D â€” RNA degradation: Performed by ribonucleases, not ribosomes.

Exam gold (high-yield)

Think â€œone mRNA â†’ many ribosomes â†’ many proteins at once.â€
Whenever efficiency or high-output protein synthesis is mentioned, the answer is polyribosomes.

Question
The centrosome contains:

Answer (Back side):
âœ… Correct answer: C â€” Two centrioles

ðŸ§  Core idea (exam focus)

Know the defining feature tested in the stem and match it to the best option.
â†’ The term â€œcentrosomeâ€ is key â€” it specifically refers to the microtubule-organizing center of the cell that includes two centrioles.

ðŸ” Mechanism / reasoning

Match the key term in the stem to the defining feature of the correct option.
â†’ Centrosome = two perpendicular centrioles + pericentriolar material (not involved in secretion or surface structures).

âŒ Why the other options are not

  • A: Microvilli
    âž¡ï¸ Surface projections for absorption â€” unrelated to the centrosome.
  • B: Actin filaments
    âž¡ï¸ Part of the cytoskeleton â€” not a structural component of the centrosome.
  • D: Golgi vesicles
    âž¡ï¸ Involved in secretion and protein modification â€” unrelated to the centrosome.

âœ¨ Exam gold (high-yield tip)

Use keywords in the stem to rule out distractors:

Which type of cilia is involved in embryonic development rotation?

Answer (Back side):
âœ… Correct answer: B â€” Nodal cilia

Core facts (exam-critical):
  • Nodal cilia = 9+0 (non-motile axoneme)
  • They lack the central pair of microtubules.
  • Despite being 9+0, nodal cilia are functionally motile due to dynein arms, generating a leftward fluid flow during gastrulation.
Why this matters clinically / embryologically:
  • The leftward flow establishes leftâ€“right asymmetry (e.g., heart looping).
  • Defects â†’ laterality disorders (e.g., situs inversus, heterotaxy).
High-yield contrast (lock it in):
  • Motile cilia (trachea, fallopian tube): 9+2
  • Primary cilium (most cells, sensory): 9+0, non-motile
  • Nodal cilium: 9+0, motile for symmetry breaking

ðŸ§  Core idea (exam focus)

Identify specialized cilia and their role in early embryonic development.
â†’ Nodal cilia are unique to the embryonic node and critical for left-right axis determination via rotational movement.

ðŸ” Mechanism / reasoning

Match the function in the stem (rotation in development) with the specialized structure (nodal cilia) known for that role.
â†’ Nodal cilia rotate to generate a unidirectional flow of fluid, which helps establish body symmetry.

âŒ Why the other options are not

  • A: Primary cilia
    âž¡ï¸ Non-motile, sensory in function â€” do not rotate or move fluid.
  • C: Motile cilia
    âž¡ï¸ Move fluid across surfaces (e.g., respiratory tract) â€” not involved in embryonic symmetry.
  • D: Stereocilia
    âž¡ï¸ Actually non-motile microvilli â€” found in the inner ear and epididymis, not true cilia.

âœ¨ Exam gold (high-yield tip)

Look for â€œrotationâ€ + â€œembryonicâ€ in the stem â†’ instantly think of nodal cilia (critical for symmetry development).

Which type of epithelium lines the bladder?

Which type of epithelium lines the bladder?

  • The urinary bladder must expand and contract repeatedly without losing its barrier function.
  • Transitional epithelium (urothelium) is uniquely adapted for this:
    • Stratified appearance

    • Maintains impermeability to urine during stretching

  • B Simple cuboidal â†’ secretion/absorption (kidney tubules), not distension
  • D Pseudostratified â†’ respiratory tract, cilia, mucus production

One-line exam rule

Stretch + urine barrier = transitional epithelium.

Clinical correlation

Loss or dysplasia of urothelium â†’ transitional cell carcinoma (most common bladder cancer).

Which week marks the beginning of organogenesis?

The Contradiction Explained

There is a conflict between the Answer Key and the Scientific Reasoning in your screenshot:
  • The Key says: Week 4 (Option C).
  • The Reasoning says: Week 3.
The Scientific Truth: Organogenesis begins in Week 3. By day 18â€“21, the neural plate is forming (nervous system) and the heart tubes are fusing and beginning to beat. These are the very first steps of organ formation.
The Exam Logic: Some exams consider Week 4 the start because that is when "gross" organogenesis (visible folding and limb buds) becomes prominent. However, since your own "Mechanism" section says Week 3, the "C â€” 4th" label is likely a typo in the appâ€™s database.

2. The Embryonic Timeline (Weeks 1â€“8)

To keep these straight for the exam, visualize the development in these distinct blocks:
PeriodKey Events
Week 1Pre-embryonic: Fertilization, cleavage, and formation of the blastocyst.
Week 2"Rule of Twos": Two germ layers (epiblast/hypoblast), two cavities (amnion/yolk sac).
Week 3Gastrulation: Formation of the 3 germ layers (Ectoderm, Mesoderm, Endoderm). Organogenesis Begins (Heart and CNS).
Weeks 4â€“8Organogenesis Peak: Rapid development of all major systems; the embryo folds into a C-shape.

3. High-Yield "Exam Gold"

If you see this question on a real exam, look at the options carefully:
  • If both 3 and 4 are options: Choose Week 3 (based on the start of gastrulation and the neural tube).
  • Why Week 3 is the "Real" Start: It is the transition from a flat disc to a 3D body. The formation of the notochord and neural plate in Week 3 are the definitive first steps of organogenesis.
  • Clinical Significance: The period from Week 3 to Week 8 is the most sensitive time for teratogens (external factors that cause birth defects) because this is when organs are being established.


Why the other options are not
  • A: Week 1 cleavage/implantation.
  • B: Week 2 bilaminar disc.
  • D: Week 8 is end of embryonic period.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Weeks 3â€“8 = embryonic period (major organ formation).

Failure of neural tube closure leads to:

Correct answers: A and B â€” Anencephaly and Spina bifida

Core idea (exam focus)

Failure of neural tube closure causes neural tube defects (NTDs). The two classic outcomes are:
  • Cranial neuropore failure â†’ Anencephaly
  • Caudal neuropore failure â†’ Spina bifida

Mechanism / reasoning

  • The neural tube forms and closes during week 3â€“4 of embryogenesis.
  • Anterior (cranial) neuropore normally closes first â†’ failure leads to absence of major parts of the brain and skull (anencephaly).
  • Posterior (caudal) neuropore closes later â†’ failure leads to defects of the vertebral arches and spinal cord (spina bifida).

  • C. Hydrocephalus
    Usually due to obstruction of CSF flow (e.g., aqueductal stenosis); it may be associated with NTDs but is not caused directly by failure of neural tube closure.
  • D. Microcephaly

  • Think neuropores:
    • Cranial â†’ anencephaly
    • Caudal â†’ spina bifida
  • Strongly associated with folate deficiency (classic MU Varna integration point)

  • Rostral failure â†’ anencephaly.

Core idea (exam focus)

Desmosomes anchor intermediate filaments, providing strong mechanical cohesion between cells.

  • Desmosomes are cellâ€“cell anchoring junctions specialized for resistance to mechanical stress.
  • Their intracellular plaques (desmoplakin, plakoglobin) bind intermediate filaments:
    • Keratins in epithelial cells

  • Desmosome = intermediate filament
  • Adherens junction = actin
  • Hemidesmosome = intermediate filament (to basal lamina)

  • This structure gives microtubules:
    • Polarity (+ and âˆ’ ends)
    • Rigidity for intracellular transport, mitotic spindle, and cilia/flagella.

Why the other options are not correct

    Keratins are intermediate filament proteins in epithelial cells.
  • C. Vimentin proteins

  • D. Neurofilaments

Exam gold (high-yield)

  • Microtubules = tubulin = 13 protofilaments
  • Intermediate filaments = keratin, vimentin, desmin, neurofilaments
  • If you see â€œprotofilamentsâ€, think microtubules, not IFs

Which substances are detected by periodic acid shift PAS staining method?

Question
Which substances are detected by periodic acid shift PAS staining method?

Correct answer: B â€” Glycol- ipids & Glycoproteins

Core idea (exam focus)

The Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is a fundamental histochemical technique used to detect polysaccharides (like glycogen) and mucosubstances (like glycoproteins and glycolipids) in tissues.
Here is a high-yield summary tailored for an Anki study card.

ðŸ”¬ PAS Stain: Quick Summary

1. Purpose & Application

  • Primary Target: Carbohydrates and glycogen.
  • Clinical Uses:
    • Identifying Glycogen Storage Diseases.
    • Detecting fungal organisms (walls are rich in polysaccharides).
    • Visualizing Basement Membranes (e.g., in kidney biopsies for glomerulonephritis).
    • Identifying mucin-secreting tumors (adenocarcinomas).

2. The Chemical Mechanism

The reaction occurs in two main steps:
  1. Oxidation: Periodic acid ($HIO_4$) oxidizes the carbon-to-carbon bonds of 1,2-glycols, converting them into dialdehydes.
  2. Coloration: The tissue is treated with Schiff reagent (leuco-fuchsin). The dialdehydes react with the reagent to form a bright magenta-colored complex.

3. Key Results (Colors)

StructureColor
PAS-Positive Material (Glycogen, Mucin, Fungi, Basement Membrane)Bright Magenta / Purplish-Red
Nuclei (if counterstained with Hematoxylin)Blue / Purple
Background (if counterstained with Light Green)Green

Where are localised the fibres of the nuclear lamina?
On the outer surface of the outer nuclear membrane
Within the lumen of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
Attached to the inner surface of the inner nuclear membrane
D. Attached to the inner surface of the inner nuclear membrane

Correct Answer: D â€” Attached to the inner surface of the inner nuclear membrane

Core Idea (Exam Focus)

The nuclear envelope is a double-membrane structure that encloses the genetic material. The nuclear lamina is a dense, fibrillar protein network that provides mechanical support to the nucleus, located specifically on its internal "ceiling."


Mechanism / Reasoning

The nuclear lamina functions as the structural scaffolding for the nucleus:
  • Location: It is positioned on the nucleoplasmic side (the inside) of the inner nuclear membrane (INM). It is tethered there by integral membrane proteins (like the lamin B receptor) and the LINC complex.
  • Composition: It is composed of lamins (A, B, and C), which are a specific type of intermediate filament.
  • Function: Beyond structural support, it provides attachment sites for chromatin, helping to organize the DNA within the 3D space of the nucleus.

Why the Other Options are Incorrect

Understanding the spatial organization of the nuclear envelope is key to excluding these distractors:
OptionReason for Exclusion
A: Outer surface of the outer nuclear membraneThis surface faces the cytoplasm and is often continuous with the Rough ER. It is usually studded with ribosomes, not the nuclear lamina.
B: Suspended within the nucleoplasmWhile some soluble lamin proteins can be found in the nucleoplasm, the lamina refers specifically to the organized meshwork layer at the periphery.
C: Lumen of the Rough ERThe lumen of the RER is continuous with the perinuclear space (the gap between the two membranes), but it is a site for protein folding, not structural filament localization.

Exam Gold (High-Yield)

  • The "Lamin" Identity: If you see the word "Lamins," immediately think Intermediate Filaments and Nuclear Structure.
  • Mitosis Regulation: During prophase, the nuclear lamina is phosphorylated, which causes the nuclear envelope to break down. Dephosphorylation at the end of mitosis allows the envelope to reform.
  • Clinical Correlation (Laminopathies): Defective lamins lead to severe diseases. The most famous is Hutchinson-Gilford Progeria Syndrome, where a mutation in Lamin A causes premature aging due to a "crinkled" or unstable nuclear shape.
  • The LINC Complex: This complex physically bridges the nuclear lamina (inside) to the cytoskeleton (outside), allowing the cell to move or position its nucleus mechanically.

Which of the following regarding cell shape is not true?

Core idea (exam focus)


 Cell shape reflects function. Muscle cells are specialized for contraction, not epithelial packing.
Mechanism / reasoning
  • Smooth muscle cells are spindle-shaped (fusiform) with tapered ends and a single central nucleus.
  • This elongated shape allows efficient contraction and shortening along the cellâ€™s long axis.
  • Cuboidal shape is characteristic of certain epithelial cells, not muscle cells.
Why the other options are not correct
  • A. Red blood cells are biconcave discs: True. This shape increases surface area and flexibility for gas exchange.
  • B. Neurons have long, thin extensions: True. Axons and dendrites allow long-distance signal transmission.
  • C. Columnar epithelial cells are tall and narrow: True. Typical of intestinal lining, optimized for absorption and secretion.
Exam gold (high-yield)
If you see cuboidal / squamous / columnar, think epithelium.
If you see elongated, spindle-shaped, think muscle (smooth muscle = fusiform).

Correct answer: D â€” Intermediate filament receptors


Core idea (exam focus)
Integrins link the extracellular matrix (ECM) to the cell, mainly through actin filaments, not intermediate filaments.
Mechanism / reasoning
  • Integrins are transmembrane heterodimers made of Î±- and Î²-subunits.
  • They bind ECM components (e.g., fibronectin, laminin, collagen) extracellularly.
  • Intracellularly, they connect to the actin cytoskeleton via adaptor proteins (talin, vinculin, paxillin).

    • Outside-in signaling: ECM binding triggers intracellular signaling pathways.

  • Structures linked to intermediate filaments include desmosomes and hemidesmosomes, using proteins like desmogleins, desmocollins, and plectin (not integrins as primary IF receptors).

are formed by budding from the trans-Golgi network (TGN)

B. Are returned to the Rough ER for recycling

Question

Correct answer: B â€” Are returned to the Rough ER for recycling

Core idea (exam focus)

Why the other options are true:

To help you study for the MU Varna exams, here is the breakdown of the "true" characteristics of secretory granules:
  • Origin (Option A): Proteins are synthesized in the RER and modified in the Golgi. The final "packaging" into granules happens at the trans-face of the Golgi.
  • The "False" Logic (Option B): Secretory granules are a "one-way" street. Once they leave the Golgi, they head for the plasma membrane. While the membrane of the granule might be recycled via endocytosis after the contents are released, it usually returns to the Golgi or lysosomes, never back to the Rough ER.
  • Transport (Option C): Granules don't just float; they are transported by motor proteins (like kinesin) along the "tracks" of the cytoskeleton (microtubules).
  • Release (Option D): This is the definition of exocytosis. In many cells (like pancreatic acinar cells), this is "regulated," meaning it only happens when a signal (like Calcium) tells the granule to fuse with the cell membrane.

Pro-Tip for MU Varna Histology Exams:

Keep an eye out for questions regarding polarized cells (like glandular epithelium). In these cells, secretory granules are almost always found at the apical pole (the top of the cell), while the nucleus and RER are at the basal pole.

Extracellular proteins are hydrophilic and cannot cross the lipid bilayer.

High-yield explanation (exam-oriented)

Core idea (1 sentence):
Intracellular targeting of vesicles depends on specific pairing between vesicle SNAREs (v-SNAREs) and target membrane SNAREs (t-SNAREs), which ensures correct docking and fusion.

Mechanism (what actually happens)

  • Transport vesicles bud from a donor membrane carrying v-SNARE proteins.
  • Target membranes (e.g., Golgi, ER, plasma membrane) express complementary t-SNAREs.
  • v-SNARE â†” t-SNARE binding is highly specific, functioning like a molecular zip code.
  • This interaction:
    • docks the vesicle,
    • brings membranes into close proximity,
    • enables membrane fusion.

Why the other options are wrong (classic traps)

  • A. Proteins (too vague)
    SNAREs are proteins, but the question asks for the specific mechanism, not the general category.
  • C. Carbohydrates
    Important for cellâ€“cell recognition and glycosylation, not vesicle targeting.
  • D. Phagocytes
    Whole cells involved in immunity, irrelevant to intracellular vesicle trafficking.

Clinical & exam relevance

  • Defects in SNARE function impair secretion (e.g., neurotransmitter release).
  • Botulinum and tetanus toxins act by cleaving SNARE proteins â†’ blocked vesicle fusion.
  • Frequently tested distinction:
    Vesicle formation = coat proteins (COPI, COPII, clathrin)
    Vesicle targeting/fusion = SNAREâ€“SNARE interactions

A Barr body is the inactive X chromosome in a female somatic cell. It appears as a dense, darkly staining spot at the edge of the nucleus during interphase. This structure is a classic example of facultative heterochromatinâ€”DNA that has been tightly packed to silence gene expression.


Why it Corresponds to Heterochromatin

To understand why Option D is correct, it helps to distinguish between the two types of chromatin found in the nucleus:
  • Euchromatin: Loosely packed DNA that is transcriptionally active (meaning genes are being "read" and used to make proteins).
  • Heterochromatin: Tightly coiled, condensed DNA that is transcriptionally inactive.
The Barr body is formed through a process called Lyonization, where one of the two X chromosomes in females is "switched off" to ensure that females don't have twice as many X-chromosome gene products as males (who only have one X). Because this chromosome is inactive and highly condensed, it fits the definition of heterochromatin.

Breaking Down the Other Options

  • A) Endothelial cells: While Barr bodies can be observed in endothelial cells (and most other somatic cells in females), they are not "equivalent" to the cell itself.
  • B) Mitosis: Barr bodies are actually most distinct during interphase, when the rest of the DNA is in a relaxed (euchromatin) state. During mitosis, all chromosomes condense, making the specific Barr body harder to distinguish from the others.
  • C) Carbohydrates: Chromatin is composed of DNA and proteins (histones), not carbohydrates.

Major mitochondrial compartments are..All are true except?

The correct answer is B: Mitochondrial pores.
In cell biology, "compartments" refer to the specific physical spaces or chambers separated by membranes. While mitochondrial pores (formed by proteins called porins) are vital structures located in the outer membrane, they are considered structural components or channels rather than distinct compartments themselves.

The Four Major Mitochondrial Compartments

Mitochondria are double-membrane organelles, and this architecture creates four primary functional areas:
  1. The Outer Membrane: The smooth, outer boundary that contains porins.
  2. The Intermembrane Space: The narrow region between the inner and outer membranes where the proton gradient (A) is established.
  3. The Inner Membrane: This membrane contains the protein complexes for the electron transport chain and ATP synthase (C). Its folds are known as cristae (D), which significantly increase the surface area for energy production.
  4. The Matrix: The innermost large chamber containing enzymes, mitochondrial DNA, and ribosomes.

Why "Mitochondrial Pores" is the odd one out:

  • Proton Gradient (A): While a gradient is a concentration difference, it defines the chemical environment of the intermembrane space compartment.
  • ATP Synthase (C): This is a massive protein complex that is often considered a functional marker of the inner membrane compartment.
  • Cristae (D): These are the physical folds of the inner membrane that create distinct sub-compartments (the intracristal space).
  • Mitochondrial Pores (B): These are individual protein channels (Porins/VDAC) located within a membrane. They facilitate the movement of molecules between the cytosol and the intermembrane space but are not "rooms" or "compartments" in their own right.

Apoptosis is defined as programmed cell death, a tidy and highly regulated process. In contrast, necrosis is "accidental" cell death, which is messy and typically causes an inflammatory response.

Why the others are TRUE for Apoptosis:

  • A - Cell shrinkage: This is a hallmark morphological feature. The cell's cytoplasm condenses and the overall volume decreases.
    • Shutterstock
  • B - Caspases: These are the "executioner" enzymes (cysteine proteases) that are activated to carry out the dismantling of the cell.
  • D - A spontaneous process: While apoptosis is "programmed" and "regulated," it is often described in medical literature as an active, "spontaneous" suicide program once a specific threshold or trigger is reached. It is an internal process the cell performs on itself.

Why C (Inflammation) is the EXCEPTION:

Apoptosis is specifically designed to be immunologically silent. Because the cell breaks down into neat, membrane-bound "apoptotic bodies" that are quickly eaten by macrophages, the toxic contents of the cell never leak out.
  • Inflammation occurs during Necrosis, where the cell membrane ruptures and spills its contents, "alarming" the immune system.

Comparison Summary

FeatureApoptosis (Programmed)Necrosis (Accidental)
Cell SizeShrinkageSwelling
InflammationNo (Silent)Yes (Messy)
MechanismCaspase-mediatedLoss of membrane integrity
PhagocytosisEfficiently clearedCauses tissue damage

Which of the cytoskeletal proteins is components of nuclear lamina?

The nuclear lamina is a dense fibrillar meshwork (30â€“100 nm thick) located just beneath the inner nuclear membrane. It is primarily composed of Type V intermediate filaments known as lamins.
Key Characteristics of Lamin Filaments 
  • Composition: In mammals, the lamina consists of A-type lamins (lamins A and C, encoded by the LMNA gene) and B-type lamins (lamins B1 and B2, encoded by LMNB1 and LMNB2).
  • Structure: Unlike cytoplasmic intermediate filaments (typically 10 nm in diameter), mature nuclear lamin filaments are approximately 3.5 nm thick. They possess a central
    Î±alpha
    ð›¼
    -helical rod domain that is 42 amino acids longer than that of cytoplasmic filaments.
  • Unique Motifs: Lamins contain a Nuclear Localization Signal (NLS) for nuclear entry and a C-terminal CaaX motif (except for lamin C) that facilitates membrane anchoring via farnesylation.
  • Mechanical Properties: These filaments are highly extensible and tough, capable of absorbing significant energy to protect the genome from mechanical stress.

Mitochondrial ATP synthase is involved in?

B â€” Oxidative phosphorylation


How to think about this without confusion

ATP synthase is the enzyme that makes ATP using the proton gradient generated by the electron transport chain.
That entire coupled process is called oxidative phosphorylation.

Mechanistic chain (lock the logic)

  1. Electron transport chain pumps protons (Hâº) into the intermembrane space
  2. This creates a proton gradient
  3. Protons flow back through ATP synthase
  4. ATP is synthesized from ADP + Pi
    âž¡ï¸ This = oxidative phosphorylation

Why the other options are wrong (exam traps)

  • A Cristae âŒ Location, not a process
    (ATP synthase is located on cristae, but not â€œinvolved in cristaeâ€)
  • C ATP synthase âŒ Circular definition (enzyme â‰  process)
  • D Proton gradient âŒ Driving force, not the named process

One-line exam memory hook

â€œProton gradient drives ATP synthase â†’ oxidative phosphorylation.â€


Understanding the Role of ATP Synthase

Mitochondrial ATP synthase (also known as Complex V) is an enzyme complex located in the inner mitochondrial membrane.1 Its function is often described through the Chemiosmotic Theory:
  • The Power Source: The Electron Transport Chain (ETC) pumps protons ($H^+$) into the intermembrane space, creating a high concentration (a proton-motive force).
  • The Mechanism: ATP synthase acts like a molecular turbine. As protons flow back into the mitochondrial matrix through the enzyme, the energy from this flow causes a part of the protein to rotate.
  • The Output: This mechanical rotation changes the conformation of the enzymeâ€™s catalytic sites, allowing it to convert ADP and inorganic phosphate (2$P_i$) into ATP.3

Why the other options are related but not the primary answer:

  • Cristae (A): This is the location. The inner membrane folds into cristae to increase the surface area available for ATP synthase, but the enzyme is "involved in" a process, not a structure.
  • ATP Synthase (C): This is simply the name of the enzyme itself.
  • Proton Gradient (D): This is the driver. The enzyme uses the gradient as fuel, but the process it completes is oxidative phosphorylation.

Core idea (exam focus)

H&E staining distinguishes cellular components by charge and affinity, not by specific chemical reactions like PAS or silver stains.

Mechanism (how H&E works)

  • Hematoxylin (basic dye, after oxidation to hematein + mordant) binds to basophilic structures:
    • Nuclei (DNA, RNA)
    • Ribosomes, RER
      â†’ stains blue to purple
  • Eosin (acidic dye) binds to acidophilic structures:
    • Cytoplasm
    • Mitochondria
    • Collagen
      â†’ stains pink to red
Therefore:
Basophilic structures are blue/purple, not red.

Why the other options are incorrect

  • A â€” Hematoxylin: Incomplete; this is just the name of the dye, not a true statement.
  • C â€” PAS reaction: A different histochemical stain (carbohydrates, glycogen, basement membranes), not part of H&E.
  • D â€” Silver impregnation: Used for reticular fibers, neurons, basement membranes; not related to H&E.

Exam gold (high-yield)

If the question mentions H&E:
  • Blue/purple = basophilic (hematoxylin)
  • Pink/red = acidophilic (eosin)
Any answer mixing H&E with PAS or silver stains is a trap.

Which one of the following is a correct statement concerning Haversian systems (osteons)?

  • Osteons (Haversian systems) are the basic structural and functional units of mature (lamellar) compact bone.

  • D: Osteons are vascular, precisely because they contain Haversian canals.

which of the following connective tissue cells modulates the allergic reactions?

Question
Which of the following connective tissue cells modulates the allergic reactions?
Correct answer: A â€” Eosinophilic leucocyte


Core idea (exam focus)
Allergic (type I hypersensitivity) reactions are driven by mast cells, but eosinophils modulate/limit the reaction.
eosinophilic leucocyte (eosinophil) is the correct answer for this question.
While mast cells are often the primary cells associated with triggering an allergic response, eosinophils play a critical role in modulating (regulating or dampening) that response.

Why Eosinophils?

In the context of connective tissue and immunology, eosinophils modulate allergic reactions through several specific mechanisms:
  • Enzyme Release: They release enzymes like histaminase and arylsulfatase, which break down inflammatory mediators (histamine and leukotrienes) released by mast cells. This helps prevent the allergic reaction from becoming excessive.
  • Phagocytosis: They can phagocytose (engulf) antigen-antibody complexes.
  • Regulation: They act as a "check and balance" system to limit the spread of local inflammation.

Why the other options are incorrect:

  • B. Fibroblast: These are the most common connective tissue cells, primarily responsible for secreting the extracellular matrix and collagen for structural support.
  • C. Macrophage: These are phagocytic cells that act as "scavengers" to clear debris and pathogens; while they are part of the immune response, they are not the primary modulators of allergic reactions.
  • D. Osteoclast: These are specialized cells found in bone tissue responsible for bone resorption (breaking down bone minerals).
Mechanism / reasoning
Eosinophils dampen allergic inflammation (e.g., histaminase/arylsulfatase), and their granules target parasites but also modulate hypersensitivity.
Why the other options are not
Plasma cells make antibodies (Ig). Fibroblasts synthesize ECM. Chondrocytes are cartilage cells, not allergy modulators.
Exam gold (high-yield)
Mast cell = triggers (histamine). Eosinophil = modulates/late-phase control + antiparasitic granules.

According to the cell theory, which scientist is credited with discovering that all living things are comprised of cells in 1665?

Glycolysis is an anaerobic process that occurs entirely in the cytosol. It does not require mitochondria and precedes aerobic metabolism.

What is the primary function of the Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum (SER) in hepatocytes?

In hepatocytes, the SER is highly developed and functions in lipid synthesis and detoxification via cytochrome P450 enzymes.

Correct answer: A â€” Detoxification and lipid synthesis

Exam-grade reasoning (MU-Varna logic)

In hepatocytes, the primary function of the Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum (SER) is:
  • Detoxification of endogenous and exogenous substances
    (via cytochrome P450 enzymes)
  • Synthesis of lipids, especially phospholipids and steroids
This is exactly what Junqueira emphasizes for liver cells:
In liver cells, SER enzymes (cytochrome P450) detoxify drugs, alcohol, and process bile components, and synthesize membrane lipids.
Therefore, option A best captures the cell-typeâ€“specific primary role of SER in hepatocytes.

Why the other options are wrong (classic traps)

  • B. Protein synthesis for secretion âŒ
    â†’ This is the function of the Rough ER (RER), which has bound ribosomes.
    SER lacks ribosomes and does not synthesize proteins.
  • C. Digestion of macromolecules âŒ
    â†’ This is the function of lysosomes, not the ER.
  • D. Sorting of secretory products âŒ
    â†’ This is a function of the Golgi apparatus, especially the trans-Golgi network.

High-yield comparison anchor (SER vs others)

  • SER (liver) â†’ detoxification + lipid synthesis
  • RER â†’ protein synthesis
  • Golgi â†’ modification & sorting
  • Lysosome â†’ digestion

One-line exam memory

SER in hepatocytes = detox + lipids
RER = proteins, Golgi = sorting, lysosome = digestion
Which organelle acts as the "post office" of the cell, initiating packing, concentration, and storage of secretory products?

A â€” Golgi apparatus

Core concept (why â€œpost officeâ€ = Golgi)

The Golgi apparatus:
  • Receives proteins and lipids from the rough ER
  • Modifies them (e.g., glycosylation)
  • Sorts, packages, concentrates, and stores secretory products
  • Directs them to their final destination:
    • Plasma membrane
    • Lysosomes
    • Secretory vesicles
This is why it is classically called the â€œpost office of the cell.â€

High-yield refinement (exam precision)

  • Cis-Golgi â†’ receives vesicles from RER
  • Medial Golgi â†’ processing/modification
  • Trans-Golgi network (TGN) â†’ final sorting and dispatch (often tested)

Why the other options are wrong (fast elimination)

  • B Nucleus âŒ genetic control, not packaging
  • C Mitochondria âŒ ATP production
  • D Rough ER âŒ protein synthesis, not final sorting

Actin microfilaments are primarily involved in:

B: Cell movement and shape.
Here is the breakdown of why Option A is incorrect for actin, and how the different "filaments" of the cell divide their labor:

1. The Mitotic Spindle (Microtubules, not Actin)

The mitotic spindle is composed of microtubules, which are made of a protein called tubulin. While actin is involved in cell division, its role is specifically at the very end during cytokinesis, where it forms the "contractile ring" to pinch the cell into two. It does not form the spindle fibers that pull chromosomes apart.

2. Primary Roles of Actin (Microfilaments)

Actin is like the "muscle" and "flexible skin" of the cell. Its primary jobs include:
  • Cell Movement: It forms pseudopods (false feet) for amoeboid movement and allows cells like white blood cells to crawl.
  • Cell Shape: It forms a dense network just under the plasma membrane (the cortex) to give the cell its surface shape.
  • Muscle Contraction: It works with myosin to make muscles move.

Comparison of Cytoskeletal Elements

To help you keep them straight for future questions, here is a quick cheat sheet:
FeatureMicrofilaments (Actin)Microtubules (Tubulin)Intermediate Filaments
Primary JobMovement, shape, & pinching cells in two.Organelle transport & the mitotic spindle.Mechanical strength & nuclear stability.
StructureTwo intertwined strands.Hollow tubes.Fibrous "ropes" (like keratin).

What is the approximate maximum thickness of the glycocalyx (cell coat) on the plasma membrane?
The glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich coat; in many cells it can reach about 100 nm in thickness.
How often is the glycocalyx (cell coat) typically renewed?

Glycocalyx components are dynamic and are renewed frequently, commonly described as every 6â€“8 hours.

The correct answer is A: Every 6â€“8 hours.
The glycocalyx, or cell coat, is a dynamic and highly active layer. Because it is constantly exposed to mechanical forces (like blood flow), chemical enzymes, and interactions with other cells, it must be continuously maintained.

Why is it renewed so quickly?

The glycocalyx is primarily composed of glycoproteins and glycolipids that are synthesized in the Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER) and processed in the Golgi apparatus. Here is why its turnover rate is so high:
  • Continuous Secretion: New components are packaged into vesicles and transported to the plasma membrane via exocytosis.
  • Degradation: Old or damaged components are either shed into the extracellular environment or internalized (endocytosed) and broken down by lysosomes.
  • Protection: Since the glycocalyx acts as the cell's first line of defense and a "molecular sieve," maintaining its integrity is vital for cell signaling and protection.

Breakdown of the Options:

  • A (6â€“8 hours): This is the typical physiological turnover rate for the majority of the glycocalyx components in active cells.
  • B (24 hours): While some specific components might last this long, the structure as a whole begins significant turnover much earlier.
  • C & D (Days to Weeks): These timeframes are far too long; the cell surface would be significantly compromised if the coat were not replaced faster.
  • E (Not renewed): This is incorrect; the glycocalyx is one of the most metabolically active parts of the cell surface.

How long after ejaculation is the maximum fertile time for most sperm?

To solve this question correctly, it is important to distinguish between the survival time of sperm (how long they stay alive) and their fertile lifespan (how long they are actually capable of fertilizing an egg).
Based on biological standards and medical consensus, the correct answer is Option D: 48 hours.

Step-by-Step Explanation

To arrive at the correct answer, you should evaluate the options based on the physiological behavior of sperm after ejaculation:
  • Initial Delay (Capacitation): Immediately after ejaculation, sperm are not yet capable of fertilizing an egg. They must spend 5 to 7 hours in the female reproductive tract undergoing a process called capacitation, which involves biochemical changes to their head and tail. This rules out very short times like 2 or 4 hours (Options A and B).
  • The Peak Fertile Window: Once capacitated, sperm reach their "maximum" fertile potential. While a small percentage of sperm can survive for up to 5 days (120 hours) under ideal conditions, the majority (most) of sperm maintain their ability to successfully penetrate and fertilize an egg for approximately 48 hours.
  • Decline in Quality: After the 48-hour mark, although many sperm may still be "swimming" (motile), their enzymatic capability to penetrate the egg's outer layer (the zona pellucida) and their DNA integrity begin to decline significantly.
  • The Fertile Window Logic: In reproductive medicine, the "fertile window" is typically defined as the 5 days before ovulation plus the day of ovulation. However, the most effective window for most sperm is considered to be the 24 to 48 hours preceding the egg's release.

Summary of Lifespans

ComponentDuration
Sperm Fertile Life (Most)48 hours
Sperm Survival (Maximum)3â€“5 days (up to 120 hours)
Egg Fertile Life12â€“24 hours
Capacitation Time5â€“10 hours

Why the other options are less likely:

  • 24 hours (Option E): While sperm are very fertile at 24 hours, they typically maintain that "maximum" capability for a full 48 hours. 24 hours is often the lifespan of the egg, not the sperm.
  • 12 hours (Option C): This is the minimum time for sperm to fully navigate the tract and reach the fallopian tubes, but they remain fertile far beyond this point.
  • 2â€“4 hours (Options A & B): These are too short; sperm are still undergoing capacitation and moving through the cervix during this window.

Approximately how long after fertilization occurs the first cleavage of the zygote?

Correct answer: A â€” ~30 hours

Core idea

  • The first cleavage of the zygote occurs at approximately 30 hours after fertilization.

Mechanism (one layer deeper)

  • This is the first mitotic division, producing two blastomeres.
  • Cleavage divisions are rapid, occur without growth, and take place while the embryo is still within the zona pellucida.

  • ~48 h â†’ 4-cell stage
  • ~72 h â†’ 8-cell stage
  • Day 4 â†’ morula
  • Day 5 â†’ blastocyst

    Clinical relevance (why this matters clinically)

    1. Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART / IVF)
    • In IVF, embryologists expect:
      • 2-cell stage at ~30 hours
    • Delayed or absent first cleavage is a poor prognostic sign and correlates with:
      • Reduced implantation rates
      • Higher risk of early embryonic arrest
    • Timing of cleavage is used as a selection criterion for embryo quality.
    2. Early pregnancy loss
    • Abnormal cleavage timing may indicate:
      • Chromosomal abnormalities
      • Defective mitotic spindle formation
    • These embryos often fail before implantation, explaining very early, clinically silent pregnancy losses.
    3. Teratology & embryotoxic exposure
    • The first cleavage occurs during the â€œall-or-noneâ€ period:
      • Severe damage â†’ embryonic death
      • Survival â†’ usually normal development
    • Important when evaluating drug exposure or radiation very early in pregnancy.
    4. Dating early development
    • Understanding cleavage timing helps distinguish:
      • Pre-implantation failure
      • vs. implantation or placentation defects
    • Useful in correlating Î²-hCG rise patterns with developmental stage.

Which of the following proteins is associated with plasmalemmal stability:

Why spectrin = plasmalemmal stability (never confuse this again)

Core concept

  • Spectrin is a cytoskeletal scaffold protein located just beneath the plasma membrane.

Which of the following cytoskeletal elements is important for the nucleus:

Why all cytoskeletal elements matter for the nucleus (clear, mistake-proof)

The nucleus is not a floating structure. It is mechanically and functionally integrated with all three cytoskeletal systems.

1) Intermediate filaments â€” structural stability (MOST IMPORTANT)

Key structure: Nuclear lamina
  • Composed of lamins (type of intermediate filament)
  • Lines the inner nuclear membrane
  • Maintains:
    • Nuclear shape
    • Nuclear mechanical strength
    • Chromatin organization
Clinical lock-in
  • Lamin defects â†’ laminopathies
    • Emeryâ€“Dreifuss muscular dystrophy
    • Hutchinsonâ€“Gilford progeria syndrome
      This alone proves IFs are essential for the nucleus.

2) Actin filaments â€” positioning & nuclear mechanics

  • Actin connects to the nucleus via the LINC complex
  • Functions:
    • Nuclear positioning
    • Nuclear movement
    • Mechanical signal transmission (mechanotransduction)
  • Important in:
    • Cell migration
    • Differentiation
    • Gene regulation via nuclear tension

3) Microtubules â€” organization & division

  • Microtubules:
    • Position the nucleus within the cell
    • Are essential during mitosis
  • The mitotic spindle interacts directly with the nuclear envelope during division.

One-glance integration table

Cytoskeletal elementRole for nucleus
Intermediate filamentsNuclear shape & stability (lamina)
Actin filamentsPositioning & force transmission
MicrotubulesNuclear movement & mitosis

Ultraâ€“high-yield rule

Nuclear lamina (IFs) stabilizes the nucleus, actin positions it, microtubules divide it.
If any one were absent â†’ nuclear dysfunction.

Weakly contacting fixed and migrating cells with diverse morphology and abundant extracellular matrix rich in fine fibers correspond to which tissue?

One high-yield mental rule (memorize this)

If cells are weakly connected, varied in shape, include migrants, and sit in lots of matrix â†’ LOSE the structure â†’ loose connective tissue.

Ultra-fast exam checklist (3-second decision)

Ask yourself:
  1. Are cells tightly packed? â†’ Epithelium âŒ
  2. Is ECM abundant? â†’ Connective tissue âœ…
  3. Are cells migrating + morphologically diverse? â†’ Loose CT âœ…

Reticular connective tissue is a specialized subtype of loose connective tissue.

So:
  • All reticular connective tissue = loose connective tissue
  • Not all loose connective tissue = reticular connective tissue

How to organize this correctly in your head

1. Loose connective tissue (big category)

Includes:
  • Areolar (typical loose CT) â† most common
  • Reticular connective tissue â† specialized
  • Adipose tissue
Shared features:
  • Abundant extracellular matrix
  • Thin fibers
  • Many cell types

2. Reticular connective tissue (special case)

Defined by:
  • Reticular fibers (type III collagen)
  • Fibers form a supporting meshwork (scaffold)
  • Cells are closely associated with the fiber network
  • Typical locations:
    • Lymph nodes
    • Spleen
    • Bone marrow
Key function:
  • Structural support for immune cells

Step-by-step cognitive unpacking (how to think, not guess)

Step 1 â€” Identify the structural signals
Read the stem and highlight the discriminators:
  • Weakly contacting cells
  • Fixed + migrating cells
  • Diverse morphology
  • Abundant extracellular matrix
  • Fine fibers
These words are not decorative. They exclude entire tissue classes.
Step 2 â€” Eliminate whole categories immediately (fast pruning)
  • Any epithelium (C, D, E) â†’ âŒ impossible
    • Epithelia have tight cell contact, minimal ECM
    • Glands have organized units (acini, cords), not weakly contacting cells
So now you are down to connective tissue only:
  • A) Loose connective tissue
  • B) Lymphoid (reticular) connective tissue
Step 3 â€” Use the cell behavior rule (this is the key)
Migrating cells + diverse morphology + loose arrangement = loose connective tissue
Loose connective tissue contains:
  • Fixed cells (fibroblasts, adipocytes, macrophages)
  • Migrating cells (lymphocytes, plasma cells, mast cells)
  • Abundant ground substance
  • Fine collagen + elastic fibers
  • Immune surveillance role
This matches the stem perfectly.
Step 4 â€” Spot the reticular tissue trap
Reticular (lymphoid) connective tissue has:
  • A network (scaffold) of reticular fibers (type III collagen)
  • Closely associated lymphocytes
  • Organ-specific architecture (lymph nodes, spleen, marrow)
âŒ The stem does NOT mention:
  • Lymphoid organs
  • Reticular fiber network
  • Supporting framework
So B is a trap, not a match.

Mechanistic explanation (why A is correct)

B â€” Serous secretory divisions of an exocrine gland âŒ

C â€” Loose connective tissue âŒ

  • Has abundant extracellular matrix
  • Cells are scattered, not tightly packed

D â€” Simple columnar resorptive epithelium âŒ

  • Forms lining surfaces
  • Cells are arranged in a single layer, not clusters
  • Usually associated with absorption (e.g., intestine)

E â€” Lymphoid (reticular) connective tissue âŒ

  • Has a reticular fiber network
  • Numerous lymphocytes, not polyhedral epithelial cells
  • ECM is not scarce

One-line exam rule to remember

â€œNo ducts + tightly packed epithelial cells = endocrine.â€
Which one of the following statements is NOT true regarding the adipose tissue?

B â€” Important endocrine function âœ”

  • Adipose tissue is an active endocrine organ.
  • Secretes adipokines: leptin (satiety), adiponectin (insulin sensitivity), resistin, TNF-Î±, IL-6.
  • Clinically relevant in metabolic syndrome, insulin resistance, and inflammation.

  • White adipose tissue (WAT): unilocular adipocytes (single large lipid droplet).
  • Brown adipose tissue (BAT): multilocular adipocytes (many small droplets), rich in mitochondria.

D â€” Important metabolic function âœ”

  • Energy storage (triglycerides).
  • Energy release (lipolysis).
  • Central to glucoseâ€“lipid homeostasis.

E â€” Located subcutaneously or around internal organs âœ”

  • Subcutaneous fat: insulation, energy reserve.
  • Visceral fat: around organs (omentum, mesentery); clinically linked to cardiometabolic risk.

Adipose tissue = endocrine + metabolic + storage + insulation, not immune defense.

Which of the listed neurotransmitters are inhibitory?

âœ… Correct answer

A â€” GABA and Glycine

ðŸ“˜ Explanation

GABA and glycine are the principal inhibitory neurotransmitters in the central nervous system.
  • GABA is the main inhibitory transmitter in the brain, acting primarily via GABA_A receptors that open Clâ» channels and hyperpolarize neurons.
  • Glycine is the main inhibitory transmitter in the spinal cord and brainstem, also acting through Clâ» channelâ€“coupled receptors.
In contrast, glutamate and aspartate are excitatory, and adrenaline (epinephrine) is a modulatory catecholamine rather than a primary inhibitory neurotransmitter.

Think â€œtwo brakesâ€ in the CNS:
  • GABA = brain brake
  • Glycine = spinal cord brake
    Both open Clâ» channels, hyperpolarizing neurons and suppressing action potentials.

Students often choose answers containing glutamate because they remember it as â€œimportantâ€ in the CNS. Glutamate (and aspartate) are actually the main excitatory neurotransmitters. Another trap is adrenaline, which is a neuromodulator, not a primary inhibitory transmitter. The correct discriminator is Clâ»-mediated inhibition â†’ GABA and glycine only.
Retrograde axonal transport is executed by the protein:

âœ… Correct answer

A â€” Dynein

ðŸ“˜ Explanation

Retrograde axonal transport moves cargo from the axon terminal toward the neuronal cell body along microtubules. This transport is mediated by dynein, a motor protein that moves toward the minus (âˆ’) end of microtubules, which is oriented toward the soma.
In contrast, kinesin moves toward the plus (+) end and mediates anterograde transport (from soma to axon terminal). Synaptophysin and synaptotagmin are synaptic vesicle proteins, not motor proteins, and myosin acts on actin, not microtubules.

Think of a railway track (microtubule) with arrows pointing away from the soma.
  • Dynein = train going backward to the cell body (âˆ’ end)
  • Kinesin = train going forward to the synapse (+ end)
â€œDynein goes Down the axon back to the soma.â€

Students often confuse dynein and kinesin because both are microtubule motor proteins. The key discriminator is direction:
  • Retrograde (to soma) = dynein
  • Anterograde (to synapse) = kinesin
    Another trap is choosing myosin, which is a motor protein but works on actin filaments, not microtubules.

ðŸ“˜ Explanation

The image shows skeletal muscle fibers with branching nerve terminals ending on the muscle cell surface. These specialized synapses between a motor neuron axon terminal and a skeletal muscle fiber are myoneural (neuromuscular) junctions.
They are characterized by:
  • Terminal axonal arborizations (â€œend platesâ€)
  • Localization at the muscle fiber surface
  • Transmission via acetylcholine acting on nicotinic receptors
This structure enables conversion of a nerve impulse into muscle contraction.

Think â€œwires touching striped cablesâ€:

  • Dark, branching nerve endings sitting on the surface = motor end plates
Where a nerve branches and spreads over a muscle fiber, you are looking at a myoneural junction.

Students often misidentify these structures as myelinated nerve fibers, focusing on the dark lines instead of their terminal branching pattern.
Key discriminator:
  • Myelinated nerve fibers â†’ long, uniform fibers, no terminal arborization
  • Myoneural junctions â†’ branched nerve endings attached to muscle fibers
Another trap is choosing secretory nerve endings, which are found near glands, not striated muscle.

Correct: A â€” mixed acini
Why: Serous demilunes (Giannuzzi) are crescent-shaped serous cell caps on mucous acini, typical for mixed (seromucous) glands.

Histologyguide.com: The submandibular gland is one of the major salivary glands. It is mostly serous (95%) and minor mucous (5%).
  • Serous Cells - arranged in a tube or acinus. These polarized cells have rough endoplasmic reticulum at their base (basophilic) and secretion granules (eosinophilic) at their apex
  • Mucous Cells - polarized cells with flattened nuclei at the bottom of the cells. They are very lightly stained with a "foamy" appearance (mucous has been extracted).
    • Serous Demilune - serous cells may appear as a cap on mucous cells.

Giannuzzi demilunes (also known as the Crescents of Giannuzzi or Demilunes of Heidenhain) are crescent-shaped cellular formations found in mixed salivary glands, such as the human submandibular and sublingual glands.
They were discovered in 1865 by the Italian physiologist Giuseppe Oronzo Giannuzzi.

Key Characteristics

  • Structure: They appear as "half-moon" (demilune) caps of serous cells sitting on the distal ends of mucous acini (the secretory units of the gland).
  • Function: These serous cells secrete proteins, including the enzyme lysozyme. Lysozyme has antimicrobial properties that help degrade the cell walls of bacteria, providing a protective effect for the oral cavity.
  • Secretory Pathway: They typically empty their secretions into small channels called intercellular canaliculi, which eventually lead to the common lumen of the gland.
Exam gold: Demilunes = mixed gland (e.g., submandibular/sublingual), parotid = pure serous (no demilunes).

Plasmalemmal proteins originate from which of the listed organelles:

Correct answer: A â€” Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER)
Why this is correct (mechanism-focused):
  • Plasmalemmal (plasma membrane) proteins are integral membrane or secretory proteins.
  • They are translated on ribosomes bound to the Rough ER via a signal peptideâ€“SRP pathway.
  • During translation, these proteins are co-translationally inserted into the RER membrane or lumen, establishing their membrane topology.
  • From the RER, they move RER â†’ Golgi â†’ plasma membrane via vesicular trafficking.
Why the others are incorrect (exam traps):
  • Smooth ER: lipid synthesis, detoxification, CaÂ²âº handling; no ribosomes â†’ no protein synthesis.
  • Golgi: modifies, sorts, and packages proteins; does not synthesize them.
  • Lysosome: degradation.
  • Peroxisome: oxidative metabolism; proteins are imported post-translationally from cytosol, not destined for plasma membrane insertion.
Clinical/exam integration (high yield):
  • Defects in SRP, signal peptide, or RER translocation â†’ mislocalization of membrane proteins.
  • Expect MU-Varna style questions linking RER + ribosomes + membrane/secretory pathway.
Quick check (active recall):
  • If a protein lacks a signal peptide, where is it synthesized, and can it become a plasma membrane protein?

Which cells can return to the blood from the tissues through diapedesis?

Correct answer: Lymphocytes

Why this is correct (exam-relevant)

  • Lymphocytes are the only blood cells that continuously recirculate between blood â†’ tissues â†’ blood.
  • They exit the bloodstream by diapedesis, enter tissues, and then return to the blood, primarily via the lymphatic system and thoracic duct.

Why the others are not

  • Monocytes: leave blood â†’ become macrophages in tissues; do not return to blood.
  • Histiocytes (macrophages): tissue-resident cells; no recirculation.
  • Mast cells: tissue-resident.
  • Erythrocytes: do not perform diapedesis.

Exam gold

Only lymphocytes recirculate.
Diapedesis out and return to blood = lymphocytes.

  • D â€” granulocytopoiesis â†’ regulated by G-CSF / GM-CSF
  • E â€” osteogenesis â†’ regulated by growth factors and hormones (e.g., vitamin D, PTH), not TPO

High-yield exam link

  • â†‘ TPO signaling â†’ thrombocytosis

Core idea (commit-level)

Spermiation is the release of mature spermatozoa from Sertoli cells into the lumen of the seminiferous tubules.

Mechanism (stepwise, exam-oriented)

  • During spermiogenesis, spermatids remain embedded in Sertoli cells via junctional complexes.
  • Spermiation = final step:
    • Junctions between Sertoli cells and spermatozoa are dissolved
    • Spermatozoa are released into the tubular lumen

Why the other options are wrong

  • A â€” Leydig cells

  • B â€” Primary spermatocytes

  • C â€” Secondary spermatocytes
    Transient meiotic stage, do not undergo spermiation.

Exam trap

  • Confusing spermiation (release) with spermatogenesis (entire process).
  • Any question asking â€œreleased fromâ€ â†’ think Sertoli cells.

One-line anchor

Spermiation = sperm released FROM Sertoli cells INTO the lumen.

The basic structural unit of the myofibril is:

Correct answer: C â€” Sarcomere

Core idea (non-negotiable)

  • The sarcomere is the basic structural and functional unit of a myofibril.

Mechanism (how it works)

  • A sarcomere is the segment between two Z-discs.
  • It contains:
    • Thin filaments (actin) anchored to Z-discs
    • Thick filaments (myosin) centered at the M-line
  • Muscle contraction occurs by sliding of actin over myosin, shortening the sarcomere while filament lengths remain constant.

Rapid exclusion of distractors (exam logic)

  • A Myosin filament â€” component only, not a unit
  • B Actin filament â€” component only
  • D Myofilament bundle â€” non-standard, vague term
  • E Z-disc â€” boundary of a sarcomere, not the unit itself

Clinical integration

  • Diseases like muscular dystrophies and cardiomyopathies often involve sarcomeric protein defects (e.g., titin, actin, myosin), leading to impaired contraction.

Membrane proteins that are not localized in the plasma membrane:

Why this is correct
  • Histones are nuclear proteins. They bind DNA to form nucleosomes and regulate chromatin structure and gene expression.
  • They are not membrane proteins and are never localized in the plasma membrane.
Why the other options are wrong
  • Integrins â†’ transmembrane proteins in the plasma membrane; cellâ€“matrix adhesion.
  • Cadherins â†’ transmembrane proteins in the plasma membrane; cellâ€“cell adhesion.
  • Ion channels â†’ transmembrane proteins enabling ion flow across the plasma membrane.
  • Glycoprotein receptors â†’ membrane-spanning receptors with extracellular carbohydrate chains.
Exam trap to remember
  • If an option involves DNA binding, chromatin, nucleosomes, or epigenetics, it points to nuclear proteins, not membrane proteins.
One-line recall
  • Histones = nucleus; integrins/cadherins/channels/receptors = plasma membrane.
All are true EXCEPT - organelles involved in the secretory pathway are:

Correct answer: E â€” Microtubules

Core idea (exam-critical)

  • Microtubules are NOT organelles of the secretory (endomembrane) pathway.
  • They support transport but are not part of the pathway itself.

What is the secretory pathway

The secretory pathway (endomembrane system) includes organelles that synthesize, modify, package, or digest proteins:
  • Rough endoplasmic reticulum â€” protein synthesis
  • Golgi apparatus â€” modification and sorting
  • Secretory vesicles â€” transport to membrane/exocytosis
  • Lysosomes â€” intracellular digestion (endpoint of some Golgi traffic)

Why E is the exception

  • Microtubules are cytoskeletal elements, not organelles.
  • They provide tracks for vesicle movement (via kinesin/dynein) but do not synthesize, modify, or package proteins.

One-line anti-trap rule

If itâ€™s cytoskeleton (actin, microtubules, IFs), it is NOT a secretory organelle.

Classic exam trap (important)

  • â€œInvolved in transportâ€ â‰  â€œpart of the secretory pathwayâ€
    Microtubules assist transport but are not members of the endomembrane system.
How many are the centrioles during the G2 phase of the cell cycle?

  • E â€” 8 âŒ

Which disassembly of nuclear envelope in mitosis occurs during:

    • Fragmentation of the nuclear envelope into vesicles
  • Only after this can kinetochoreâ€“microtubule attachment occur

  • A Prophase âŒ
    â†’ Chromosomes condense, spindle begins to form
    â†’ Nuclear envelope still intact
  • C Metaphase âŒ
    â†’ Chromosomes aligned at metaphase plate
    â†’ Envelope already absent
  • D Anaphase âŒ
    â†’ Sister chromatids separate
  • E Telophase âŒ
    â†’ Reassembly of the nuclear envelope occurs here

MU-Varna exam trap âš ï¸

Many textbooks loosely state â€œlate prophase,â€ but MU-Varna exams require the precise phase name: prometaphase.

5-second recall rule

Breakdown = Prometaphase
Reassembly = Telophase

    with

  • Single set â†’ haploid

  • B Neural tube â†’ âŒ Ectoderm
  • C Epithelium of renal tubules, renal calyces â†’ âœ… Mesodermal (lateral/intermediate plate context)
  • D Notochord â†’ âŒ Axial mesoderm

  • B â†’ Ectoderm (neural crest)
    â†’ Frequently mixed up with mesoderm in migration questions
  • D â†’ Axial mesoderm
    â†’ Tests axis-specific mesoderm knowledge
  • E â†’ Intermediate mesoderm

Correct answer: B â€” Mitosis

The cloacal membrane is composed of:
