The septum primum and septum secundum are involved in the formation of the:

Correct answer: B â€” Interatrial septum

Lock this in permanently (step-by-step)

Core fact (exam anchor)

  • Septum primum and septum secundum are embryonic structures that together form the interatrial septum.

How atrial septation actually works (simple but precise)

  1. Septum primum
    • Grows downward from the roof of the primitive atrium
    • Leaves a temporary gap: foramen primum
    • Foramen primum closes as septum primum fuses with endocardial cushions
  2. Foramen secundum
    • Forms by apoptosis in the upper part of septum primum
  3. Septum secundum
    • Forms to the right of septum primum
    • Leaves an opening: foramen ovale
  4. At birth
    • Increased left atrial pressure pushes septum primum against septum secundum
    • Functional closure â†’ fossa ovalis

Why the other options are wrong (exam traps)

  • A Interventricular septum âŒ
    • Formed by muscular septum + membranous part (endocardial cushions + conotruncal ridges)
  • C Aortic septum âŒ
    • Formed by conotruncal (spiral) ridges, not atrial septa
  • D Neural tube âŒ
    • Ectodermal structure, unrelated to heart septation
  • E Endocardial cushions âŒ
    • They assist closure but do not form the interatrial septum itself

High-yield clinical relevance

  • Atrial septal defects (ASDs) result from:
    • Excessive resorption of septum primum
    • Incomplete development of septum secundum
  • Patent foramen ovale (PFO):
    • Failure of postnatal fusion
    • Usually asymptomatic but linked to paradoxical embolism

One-line exam lock

Septum primum + septum secundum = interatrial septum

Which germ layer forms the adrenal medulla?

Correct: Neural crest
he adrenal medulla is formed from the Neural Crest (Option D).
The adrenal gland has a dual embryological origin, meaning its two main parts come from entirely different tissue sources.

1. Adrenal Medulla (Inner Layer)

  • Origin: Derived from Neural Crest cells, which are themselves a specialized population of the Ectoderm.
  • Function: It acts as a modified sympathetic ganglion. During development, neural crest cells migrate into the center of the developing adrenal cortex and differentiate into chromaffin cells.
  • Products: These cells secrete catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine) directly into the bloodstream as part of the "fight-or-flight" response.

2. Adrenal Cortex (Outer Layer)

  • Origin: Derived from the Mesoderm (specifically the intermediate mesoderm/coelomic epithelium).
  • Function: It develops into three distinct zonesâ€”the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.
  • Products: It produces steroid hormones such as cortisol, aldosterone, and androgens.

Comparison Summary

Adrenal PartGerm Layer OriginKey Cell TypeMajor Hormones
MedullaNeural Crest (Ectoderm)Chromaffin cellsEpinephrine, Norepinephrine
CortexMesodermCorticosteroidsCortisol, Aldosterone, DHEA

Which structure forms the central tendon of the diaphragm?

Which structure is formed at the dorsal border tip of the neural tube?

Correct answer: C â€” Neural crest

Core idea (high-yield)

  • The neural crest forms at the dorsal border (crest) of the closing neural tube during neurulation.

Mechanism (why this is correct)

  • As the neural folds elevate and fuse to form the neural tube, a specialized cell population at the junction between neural plate (neuroectoderm) and surface ectoderm undergoes epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition.
  • These cells delaminate from the dorsal neural tube and migrate extensivelyâ€”this population is the neural crest.

Rapid exclusion of distractors

  • Neural plate: the flat ectodermal thickening before tube closure.
  • Notochord: midline mesodermal rod ventral to the neural tube.
  • Somite: paraxial mesoderm segments lateral to the tube.
  • Primitive streak: early gastrulation structure (earlier stage).

Clinical integration (exam-relevant)

  • Neural crest derivatives are broad; defects cause neurocristopathies (e.g., Hirschsprung disease, DiGeorge syndrome, Waardenburg syndrome).
The cells generated by the spermatogonia are:

Core idea (high-yield)

Mechanism (sequence clarity)

  1. Spermatogonia (2n) â†’ mitosis
  2. Primary spermatocytes (2n, 4C DNA) â†’ enter meiosis I
  3. Secondary spermatocytes (1n, 2C) â†’ meiosis II
  4. Spermatids (1n, 1C) â†’ spermiogenesis â†’ spermatozoa

  • B / C Secondary spermatocytes â€” arise after meiosis I
  • E Sertoli cells â€” somatic support cells, not generated from spermatogonia

Exam trap to note

    The correct immediate product is primary spermatocytes.
The maternal and fetal components of the placenta are?

Correct answer: B â€” intervillous/basal (maternal) and chorionic plate (fetal)

Core idea (must know)

  • The placenta has a maternal part and a fetal part.
  • Maternal component: decidua basalis â†’ intervillous space (filled with maternal blood)
  • Fetal component: chorionic plate (with chorionic villi)

Mechanism (anatomical logic)

  • Maternal blood from uterine spiral arteries enters the intervillous space, bathing the villi.
  • Fetal blood circulates within chorionic villi, which arise from the chorionic plate.
  • No direct mixing of maternal and fetal blood occurs; exchange happens across the placental barrier.

Why B is correct

  • Intervillous/basal (maternal) = functional maternal side
  • Chorionic plate (fetal) = fetal surface from which villi extend
This pairing correctly matches maternal vs fetal origin.

Rapid exclusion of distractors (classic exam traps)

  • A Decidua capsularis and amnion â€” capsularis degenerates; amnion is fetal but not placental exchange tissue
  • C Chorion frondosum and yolk sac â€” yolk sac is not part of the placenta
  • D Amnion (maternal) â€” amnion is fetal, not maternal
  • E Myometrium â€” uterine muscle, not placental tissue

Clinical anchor

  • Abnormal implantation into the decidua basalis leads to placenta accreta spectrum (accreta, increta, percreta).
From which layer originates the chorion?

Correct answer: C â€” Extraembryonic mesoderm

Core idea (exam-critical)

  • B Endoderm â€” gut/respiratory epithelia

  • E Paraxial mesoderm â€” somites (dermis, muscle, bone)

Which are the risks of pregnant women in case of a tubal pregnancy?

What compartment of the blastocyst contributes to the formation of the placenta?

Correct answer: B â€” Trophoblast
(The marked answer D is incorrect.)

Core idea (must lock in)

  • E Amnion â€” extraembryonic membrane, not placental origin

Which of the following lists are steps in in-vitro fertilization procedure?
"Ovarian hyperstimulation- Natural IVF- Final maturation induction- egg

Correct answer: C â€” Ovarian hyperstimulation â†’ (Natural/controlled) IVF â†’ final maturation induction â†’ egg retrieval â†’ fertilization â†’ embryo culture â†’ transfer

Core idea (what IVF actually includes)

  • IVF is a clinical procedure, not an embryology timeline.
  • It consists of hormonal preparation, oocyte retrieval, fertilization in vitro, embryo culture, and embryo transfer.

Correct procedural sequence (exam-appropriate)

  1. Ovarian hyperstimulation (controlled stimulation with gonadotropins)
  2. Final oocyte maturation induction (e.g., hCG or GnRH agonist)
  3. Egg (oocyte) retrieval
  4. In vitro fertilization (standard IVF or ICSI)
  5. Embryo culture (cleavage/blastocyst)
  6. Embryo transfer to uterus

Why the other options are wrong (classic traps)

  • A Implantation/gastrulation â€” post-transfer embryonic events, not IVF steps
  • B Cleavage/compaction/neurulation â€” developmental stages, not a procedure
  • D Oogenesis/spermatogenesis â€” gametogenesis, occurs in the body
  • E ICSI only â€” just one fertilization technique, not the whole IVF process

One-line anti-trap rule

If itâ€™s hormones, retrieval, lab fertilization, culture, transfer â†’ IVF.
If itâ€™s cleavage/gastrulation â†’ embryology, not IVF.

Which of the following is not known to be human teratogen?

Correct answer: D â€” Ribociclib (Novartis) and Palbociclib

Core idea (high-yield)

  • Human teratogens = agents with proven congenital malformations in humans.
  • Options A, B, C, E are classic, exam-defining human teratogens.
  • CDK4/6 inhibitors (ribociclib, palbociclib) do not have established human teratogenicity (human evidence lacking).

Why the others are teratogens (mechanism â†’ clinical relevance)

  • Alcohol
    • Mechanism: neuronal apoptosis, disrupted migration
    • Clinical: Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (facial anomalies, neurodevelopmental delay)
  • Isotretinoin
    • Mechanism: retinoic acid signaling disruption
    • Clinical: craniofacial, cardiac, thymic, CNS defects
    • Exam keyword: â€œabsolute contraindication in pregnancyâ€
  • Thalidomide
    • Mechanism: anti-angiogenesis
    • Clinical: phocomelia, limb reduction defects
  • Valproate
    • Mechanism: folate antagonism, histone deacetylase inhibition
    • Clinical: neural tube defects (esp. spina bifida)

Why D is correct

  • Ribociclib / Palbociclib (CDK4/6 inhibitors):
    • Known: embryotoxicity in animal studies
    • Not proven human teratogens
    • Exam logic: â€œNot knownâ€ â‰  â€œsafeâ€, but â‰  â€œestablished teratogenâ€

Exam trap to notice

  • Mixing thalidomide (true teratogen) in the option text is a decoy.
  • The question asks which is NOT known â†’ focus on human evidence, not theoretical risk.

Elongated eosinophilic structural syncytia with regular transverse striations and round peripherally located nuclei indicate which tissue?

Correct answer: B â€” Transversely striated skeletal muscle tissue

Lock-in explanation (so you never miss this again)

The four decisive clues in the stem

  1. Elongated fibers
  2. Eosinophilic cytoplasm (pink, protein-rich myofibrils)
  3. Regular transverse striations
  4. Round nuclei located peripherally
When these appear together, they point to skeletal muscleâ€”not cardiac, not smooth, not epithelium.

Why this is skeletal muscle (step by step)

1) Structural syncytium

  • Skeletal muscle fibers are multinucleated because many myoblasts fuse.
  • Result: one long cell with many nuclei â†’ â€œstructural syncytiumâ€.

2) Peripheral nuclei (the key discriminator)

  • In skeletal muscle, nuclei are pushed to the periphery by dense myofibrils.
  • This is the most reliable exam clue.

3) Regular transverse striations

  • Caused by perfectly aligned sarcomeres (A- and I-bands).
  • Striations are straight, parallel, and uniform.

4) Eosinophilic cytoplasm

  • High concentration of actin and myosin â†’ strong pink staining on H&E.

Why the other answers are wrong (exam traps)

A) Cardiac muscle âŒ

Cardiac muscle is striated, but:
  • Nuclei are central, not peripheral
  • Fibers are branched, not long parallel cylinders
  • Intercalated discs are present (zig-zag dark lines)
    If you see central nuclei + branching â†’ think cardiac.

C) Simple columnar resorptive epithelium âŒ

  • Has one nucleus per cell
  • No striations
  • Organized as a sheet, not elongated fibers

D) Loose connective tissue âŒ

  • No striations
  • Mixed cell types (fibroblasts, immune cells)
  • Abundant extracellular matrix

E) Endocrine glandular epithelium âŒ

  • Cells arranged in cords or follicles
  • No striations
  • Central nuclei, secretory appearance

One-glance comparison (exam memory table)

FeatureSkeletal muscleCardiac muscle
StriationsYesYes
Fiber shapeLong, cylindricalShort, branched
NucleiPeripheral, manyCentral, 1â€“2
Intercalated discsNoYes
ControlVoluntaryInvoluntary

Ultra-high-yield rule (memorize this)

Striations + peripheral nuclei = skeletal muscle
Striations + central nuclei + branching = cardiac muscle

How to recognize this instantly (no more confusion)

    • Tightly packed cells

  • E Skeletal muscle âŒ
    • Highly cellular, striations, no ECM abundance

One-line exam lock

Many fibers + many spaces + mixed cells = loose connective tissue

  • At ovulation, it completes meiosis I â†’ secondary oocyte + polar body, then begins meiosis II and arrests at metaphase II.
  • Completion of meiosis II occurs only after fertilization.


Why the other options are not
  • A: Before birth = prophase I arrest, not meiosis II start.
  • B: During birth is incorrect.
  • C: Puberty resumes meiosis I in selected follicles, not meiosis II start.
  • E: False because meiosis II begins at ovulation.


Exam gold (high-yield)
  • Birth: primary oocyte in prophase I.
  • Ovulation: meiosis I completes, meiosis II begins (metaphase II arrest).
  • Fertilization completes meiosis II.

Which of the statements regarding the types of spermatogionia is NOT true
Type A dark (Ad) â€“ long-term reserve
Type A pale (Ap) â€“ mitotically active
Type B â€“ progenitor generating spermatocytes
Type C - stem cell generating Sertoli cells

The statement that is NOT true is Option E: Type C - stem cell generating Sertoli cells.
Here is a breakdown of why Option E is incorrect and how the other types function within the process of spermatogenesis:

Why Option E is False

There is no such cell classified as "Type C" spermatogonia in the human spermatogenic lineage. Furthermore, Sertoli cells do not arise from spermatogonia. Sertoli cells are "nurse cells" of the testes that originate from the coelomic epithelium (mesodermal origin) during fetal development; they are non-proliferative after puberty and provide support to the germ cells.

Understanding the Spermatogonia Lineage

Spermatogonia are the undifferentiated germ cells located on the basement membrane of the seminiferous tubules. They are categorized based on their nuclear appearance and mitotic activity:
  • Type A Dark (Ad) (Option B): These have dark, dense chromatin.1 They are considered the reserve stem cells that rarely divide. They act as a fail-safe to replenish the pool if the active cells are damaged.
  • Type A Pale (Ap) (Option A & C): These have pale, granulated chromatin. They are mitotically active and undergo regular divisions to maintain the germ cell population and produce Type B cells.
  • Type B (Option D): These are the progenitor cells. Once a cell differentiates into Type B, it is committed to the pathway of becoming a sperm. Type B cells undergo mitosis to give rise to primary spermatocytes, which then enter meiosis.

Summary Table

Cell TypeCharacteristicRole
Type AdDark nucleusReserve stem cell (Quiescent)
Type ApPale nucleusActive stem cell (Renewing)
Type BLarge nucleoliDifferentiating progenitor
Sertoli Cell2Somatic cell3Support/Nutrition (Not a germ cell)4

Paraxial mesoderm primarily gives rise to which of the following?
Paraxial mesoderm forms somites; the dermatome component gives rise to the dermis of the skin.
Endoderm gives rise to which epithelial derivative?
Endoderm forms the epithelial lining of the gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts; tracheal epithelium is endoderm-derived.
Trap: urogenital epithelium is mainly from intermediate mesoderm (not endoderm in this exam mapping).
Intermediate mesoderm most directly forms which structure?
Intermediate mesoderm forms the urogenital system (kidneys and gonads) and associated epithelia.
Trap: serous membranes (pleura/pericardium/peritoneum) are from lateral plate mesoderm.
Surface ectoderm gives rise to which tissue derivative?
Surface ectoderm forms the epidermis and its appendages (hair, nails, glands).
Trap: dermis is mesoderm; epidermis is ectoderm.
Lateral plate mesoderm gives rise to which of the following?
Lateral plate mesoderm forms the serous membranes lining body cavities: pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum.
Lateral plate mesoderm â†’ serous membranes
Trap: do not assign serous membranes to intermediate mesoderm.

Which statement regarding blood-testis barrier is NOT true?
Formed by spermatogonia and other spermatogenic cells
Represents a barrier against potentially harmful substances for gametes
Separates cells into basal and adluminal compartments

Correct answer (NOT true): Formed by Leydig cells

Why this is the correct choice

Letâ€™s anchor this precisely to histology and exam logic.
Core facts about the bloodâ€“testis barrier (BTB)
  • What forms it:
    Tight junctions (zonula occludens), adherens junctions, and gap junctions between Sertoli cells.
  • Where it is:
    Inside the seminiferous tubules, between Sertoli cells.
  • What it does:
    • Divides the seminiferous epithelium into:
      • Basal compartment (spermatogonia)
      • Adluminal compartment (meiotic and post-meiotic germ cells)
    • Protects developing germ cells from:
      • Immune attack
      • Toxic substances in the blood

Quick option-by-option check (exam mindset)

  • Formed by spermatogonia and other spermatogenic cells
    âŒ Not structurally correct, but examiners usually reserve the single best false answer for Leydig cells.
  • Formed by Sertoli cells
    âœ… True â€” this is the key fact.
  • Represents a barrier against potentially harmful substances for gametes
    âœ… True.
  • Formed by Leydig cells
    âŒ FALSE
    Leydig cells are interstitial, outside the seminiferous tubules, and secrete testosterone. They have nothing to do with the BTB.
  • Separates cells into basal and adluminal compartments
    âœ… True.

High-yield exam rule (remember this)

Bloodâ€“testis barrier = Sertoliâ€“Sertoli junctions
Leydig cells = testosterone, interstitium, no barrier
